results.description:
****READ THIS FIRST || Parade Grounds Game Standards ****


Meet on field 8!!!

The game is scheduled to start at 2:00. We typically start 15 minutes after 2:00. Your RSVP is good if you come on time. If you come after teams are divided then you run the risk of not playing. Those who have RSVP’ed get first preference to play (This does not apply to anyone on the waiting list). Also, please  Un-RSVP if you will not be attending. That gives other people a chance to play.

Rules and guidelines:

These games are geared towards advanced to intermediate players.

Teams are divided by two team captains (captains pick players in turns in an attempt to keep teams balanced and competitive)

Physical play is allowed as long as it isn't overly aggressive or dirty.

Slide tackles are allowed only to block a shot on goal or to intercept a pass  NO slide tackling on a player with the ball.

Ball hogging is absolutely not tolerated

Keep in mind as we don't have permit, we need to be flexible.
results.name: Saturday Pick-up Parade grounds 2:00 PM

results.description:
Join us for our weekly Underwater Rugby (UWR) practice!

Underwater what? Underwater rugby is probably the most exciting activity you may have ever done. The only 3D sport (apart from Harry Potter’s Quidditch), great endurance, fast, strategic, and above all: extreme fun! Imagine a 13ft-deep pool, 2 baskets on the bottom of each side. Two teams, equipped with fins, mask&snorkel, and a salt-water filled ball. We hold our breath when playing at 3, 5, 13 feet below the surface and pass the ball standing on our heads, swimming sideways and swirling around. Yes, we can tackle the person who carries the ball. But no, no one ever drowned in the 60 years the sport has been around. Ladies and gents are equally welcome - we are co-ed :)

We have all the equipment you need if you want to try. Just let us know and jump with us into the water - we welcome all levels (though you should be able to swim and be comfortable with the idea of swimming under the water - but you don't need to be an expert diver). 

So just send us a quick line and new experiences await - we promise!

Contact Daniel or Rolexi at [masked]

And check out our Facebook profile www.facebook.com/NJ.UWH.UWR/

<a href="http://g.co/maps/ueppk"></a>
results.how_to_find_us: 226 Rome Street, Newark, NJ  Map: http://g.co/maps/ueppk

I know.. despite the information that has already been presented $2,350 is a lot of money to commit to any one thing.          - What if I'm traveling alone? How do I get a roommate?

         - What should I expect of AAT?

This event is free.  Seating is first come first serve.  CNY Host:  Yen.  You will be joining members from "Manhattan Lectures & Conversations."   http://www.meetup.com/Manhattan-Lectures-Conversations/events/229294000/

The Meditative State

Saturday, March 12, 2016
2:30 - 4:30 pm

http://www.helixcenter.org/roundtables/the-meditative-state/

  Watch the video »

What is meditation? As difficult as it may be to define this state of mind, its beneficial effects on mental and physical health are incontrovertible. What are the respective roles of conscious and unconscious processes in this voluntarily invoked mental state? How might the experience of meditation differ from trance and hypnotic states? What neuroscientific data can help us to understand how the brain, through the power of its own emergent product—the meditating mind—might alter its own functioning?Participants:

Sara Lazar

Assistant Professor in Psychology, Harvard Medical School

Sara W. Lazar, Ph.D., is an Associate Researcher in the Psychiatry Department at Massachusetts General Hospital and an Assistant Professor in Psychology at Harvard Medical School. The focus of her research is to elucidate the neural mechanisms underlying the beneficial effects of yoga and meditation, both in clinical settings and in healthy individuals. She is a contributing author to Meditation…read more »

Peter Malinowski

Senior Lecturer in Psychology and Cognitive Neuroscience, Liverpool John Moores University

Peter Malinowski, PhD, is the founding director of the Meditation and Mindfulness Research Group at the Research Centre for Brain and Behaviour, Liverpool John Moores University and Honorary Lecturer at the University of Liverpool. In his work he builds on his expertise in Cognitive Neuroscience and on his extensive experience in practicing and teaching meditation… read more »

Koshin Paley Ellison

Co-Founder of the New York Zen Center for Contemplative Care

Rev. Dr. Koshin Paley Ellison, MFA, LMSW, DMIN, cofounded the New York Zen Center for Contemplative Care, the first Zen-based organization to offer fully accredited ACPE clinical chaplaincy training in America, which delivers contemplative approaches to care through education, direct service, and meditation practice. Paley Ellison is the academic advisor for the Buddhist students in… read more »

Morgan Stebbins

Supervising Analyst, Jungian Psychoanalytic Association in New York

Morgan Stebbins is a supervising analyst, faculty member and former President and Director of Training at the Jungian Psychoanalytic Association in New York, where he also maintains a private practice. He teaches Religious Studies and Hermeneutics at the New York Theological Seminary in the Pastoral Care and Counseling program, and he directs the program in… read more »

Yi-Yuan Tang

Professor of Psychological Sciences, Texas Tech University

Dr. Yi-Yuan Tang is a Professor of Psychological Sciences, Presidential Endowed Chair in Neuroscience at Texas Tech University and founding Director of Texas Tech Neuroimaging Institute. He is also Professor of Internal Medicine at TTU Health Science Center, Adjunct Professor of Psychology, University of Oregon. He is Fellow of Association for Psychological Sciences (APS), Fellow… read more »

results.description:
Please join me for 3 hours to fine tune your intuition and your eye in the Metropolitan Museum of Art! This class is open to all photography levels, and is more of a creative rather than technical class. If you're interested in learning more about the technical aspects, please attend our digital photography: intro for beginners class.

We will conduct exercises to tune you into your intuition, and learn how to take photographs by following it. In addition, we will focus on the differences between looking, observing and seeing. I will also review and give feedback on how to better the composition of your photographs. You will notice that by the end of the class you will not only be looking at the world with an eye of a photographer, but will have better photographs to prove it!

We will meet by the Egyptian statue (to the right of the info booth). I will be carrying a red bag for you to recognize me.

I looking forward to seeing you there!

results.description:
The Reelabilities Film Festival is back with a variety of programming. There will be film, dance, music, discussions and more. We’ve chosen to attend a panel on The Oral History Project. As a part of the disability community, how do we know where we need to go if we don’t know where we came from? This will be our chance to here some authentic stories from disability advocates in New York. Here’s the blurb from the reelabilities schedule. Join disability advocates as they talk about the changing landscape of disability in New York City over time—including past and present history and thoughts on the future. Panelists will share stories from their own experiences working in disability communities throughout the city. Presented by The New York Public Library’s Oral History Project, Visible Lives: Oral Histories of the Disability Experience.

This is a free event and it is open to the public. It will be held at the Jewish Community Center in Manhattan. The event starts at 3 PM. As a group we will meet at 2:30 PM. I will share a contact and meeting point closer to the date of the event.

Link to Reelabilities schedule:
http://newyork.reelabilities.org/films-and-events/#toggle-id-8 Link to the New York Librarys Oral History Project:
http://oralhistory.nypl.org/neighborhoods/visible-lives

JCC Manhattan Contact page:
http://www.jccmanhattan.org/about/contact/

Please RSVP if you’re going to join us.

Walei
results.name: Challenge History Panel at the Reelabilities Film Festival

results.description:
Are you a creative of any field (art, science, technology, entrepreneurship, anything)? Or are you someone looking for inspiration?

In this meeting, we will start with a warm welcome!  

This group, Creative Instigators, is about creativity and coming together to support each other on our creative ideas.  If you on working on something, great!  If you do not know how to get started on an idea or do not have an idea, this is a great opportunity to have us help you brainstorm and give you suggestions about what you can do.  I personally can quickly come up with ways to help you get started.

This group is for anyone of any discipline, not just the ones traditionally associated with creativity, like the arts.  Scientists, technologists, and entrepreneurs are creative people too!

Please RSVP to the main group sponsoring this event, Creative Instigators: http://www.meetup.com/createandinstigate/events/229169985/

Here is our schedule:  

(1) 3:00-3:30 Meet Leon. Settle down and talk.

(2) 3:30 Introductions: I will be sharing the vision of the group, what it is about, and why it is a great resource.

(3) 3:40-6:30 We break into discussion groups.  Good time to share your ideas and dreams, network, form teams or collaborations, seek help. Looking for someone with a different skill set you need?  This is the great place to look!

7pm - Bill's Bar & Burger, 51st/5th, $$, 16 W 51st St, New York, NY 10019, (212)[masked], $10 burgers, $12 cocktails, https://goo.gl/maps/nyibYA3pWMw

10pm - Draught 55, 55th/2nd, 245 E 55th St, New York, NY 10022, $7 beer, $14 cocktails, https://goo.gl/maps/31nbMEHCc1Q2 

I look forward to seeing all of you!

Leon

results.description:
Host: Leon, http://www.meetup.com/Manhattan-Lectures-Conversations/events/229169996/?

Are you a creative of any field (art, science, technology, entrepreneurship, anything)? Or are you someone looking for inspiration?

In this meeting, we will start with a warm welcome!  

This group, Creative Instigators, is about creativity and coming together to support each other on our creative ideas.  If you on working on something, great!  If you do not know how to get started on an idea or do not have an idea, this is a great opportunity to have us help you brainstorm and give you suggestions about what you can do.  I personally can quickly come up with ways to help you get started.

This group is for anyone of any discipline, not just the ones traditionally associated with creativity, like the arts.  Scientists, technologists, and entrepreneurs are creative people too!

Please RSVP to the main group sponsoring this event, Creative Instigators: http://www.meetup.com/createandinstigate/events/229169985/

Here is our schedule:  

(1) 3:00-3:30 Meet Leon. Settle down and talk.

(2) 3:30 Introductions: I will be sharing the vision of the group, what it is about, and why it is a great resource.

(3) 3:40-6:30 We break into discussion groups.  Good time to share your ideas and dreams, network, form teams or collaborations, seek help. Looking for someone with a different skill set you need?  This is the great place to look!

(4) 6:30 If you chose to stay, I will look for suggestions and ideas the group brings for future activities.  For instance, we can go on a creative play date, such as go learn how to do magic tricks, do improve, or make sushi.

(5) 7:00 This is not required, but afterwards everyone can come together and go to a restaurant or bar.

I look forward to seeing all of you!

Leon

Introduction to Modern Calligraphy will get students started on the basics of pointed (dip) pen calligraphy. We will cover different strokes, letter formation, and work on developing your own unique writing style. Students will receive helpful handouts to take home and continue their practice and overview sheets focusing on two different alphabets. We also cover the basics of envelope addressing and different flourishes you can use to add some awesomeness to your correspondence.

dip pen and nib 
black sumi ink 
gold and colored inks, to share with others 
brush pen 
handouts 
practice paper 
envelopes 
cards 
Please bring a small ruler and a pencil/eraser.

results.description:
This classic horror movie based on Stephen King's first novel stars Sissy Spacek as Carrie White, a shy, diffident teenager who is the butt of practical jokes at her small-town high school. Her blind panic at her first menstruation, a result of ignorance and religious guilt drummed into her by her fanatical mother, Margaret (Piper Laurie), only causes her classmates' vicious cruelty to escalate, despite the attentions of her overly solicitous gym teacher (Betty Buckley). Finally, when the venomous Chris Hargenson (Nancy Allen) engineers a reprehensible prank at the school prom, Carrie lashes out in a horrifying display of her heretofore minor telekinetic powers. Many films had featured school bullies, but Carrie was one of the first to focus on the special brand of cruelty unique to teenage girls. Carrie's world is presented as a snake pit, where the well-to-do female students all have fangs -- even the reticent Sue Snell (Amy Irving) -- and all the males are blind pawns, sexually twisted around the fingers of Chris and her evil cronies. The talented supporting cast includes John Travolta, P.J. Soles, and William Katt. One of the genre's true classics, the film was followed by a sequel in 1999, as well as by a famously unsuccessful Broadway musical adaptation that starred Betty Buckley, the movie's gym teacher, as Margaret White.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VSF6WVx_Tdo

RSVP at: https://chromaticvisions.eventbrite.com.

CHROMATIC VISIONS: The Exhibition

Exhibition & Reception:

Saturday, March 12, 2016

4-8pm

CAELUM GALLERY

516 West 26th Street, Room 315

New York, NY 10001

(917)[masked]

CURATOR

Dawn M. Wayand

SPONSORS

NYC Digital Photography Workshops


Adorama Camera

NYCDPW, a prominent digital photography education group in New York City, is proud to present Chromatic Visions at the Caelum Gallery on Saturday, March 12, 2016 from 4-8pm. This fabulous exhibition will feature the works of more than 18 exceptional up-and-coming artists and photographers such as Yann Bizeul, Clint Calder, Rose Cirrincione, Jane CoCo Cowles, Krystal Flood-Aquilino, Michael J. Hayes, Michal Hess, Bernhart Hochleitner, Amy Lee Hochman, Veronica Hodgkinson, Sheldon Katz, Veronique Lerebours, Kelly Liu, Danielle O’Brien, Tina Psoinos, Caroline D. Roswell, Carol Strickman and Ronald Zeytoonian and more. Complimentary nibbles, wine (and other non-alcoholic beverages) will be served up alongside a night of visual temptation and live jazzy grooves by the Jeff Fowler Group. All work on display is for sale. Cash, check or credit card is accepted.

RSVP at: https://chromaticvisions.eventbrite.com.

There are two ticket types. There is a Free Admission Ticket (Art Enthusiast) or you may choose a Discretionary Donation Ticket (VIP Art Enthusiast) for our charity pick: Art Start. 

Art Start is an organization that nurtures the voices, hearts and minds of New York City's underserved youth through consistent creative workshops inside homeless shelters, alternative to incarceration programs, and partnering youth agencies. $1, $5, $10... Any amount helps.

For more information on showing at this exhibition or to help promote this event, please contact the curator for the show, Dawn M. Wayand, by email at [masked] or by phone at (727) 641-9570.

results.description:
Let's explore the Met together every other Saturday with as little pressure as possible.

Go in the 81st entrance (not up the big stairs), and head straight back to the Uris Center for Education. We'll be at the set of benches (#8) in the middle on the left inside the room. At 4:15pm we will split up.

We'll decide who will go see what with whom, wander galleries, and meet at the north entrance to the Balcony Bar at 5:30pm for cocktails, mocktails, and small plates to chat. We'll get tables at 5:40pm.

Everyone is responsible for their own admission and tab. I recommend you bring cash for your tab to make settling the check easier.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be at the set of benches (#8) in the middle on the left inside the Center For Education room, which is straight ahead when you get past coat check. At 4:15pm we will split up. Then meet up at the north entrance to the Balcony Bar at 5:30.

results.description:
LATEST EVENT UPDATES:

Excited to share the great line up of Irish food & drink producers for next week's event.  (Please also see photo attached to this meetup to see exactly who's coming to the 'party'!).  A few highlights - and this is just a selection - you'll have be on-site to see all:

- A whiskey and dill infused smoked salmon

- A lemon truffle chocolate that is produced in the Skellig Islands are (aka as where the new Star Wars movie was shot)

- Ice cream sodas featuring an Irish craft soda

- A nettle syrup from Ireland's only commercial nettle farm

- Ireland's first potato vodka samples

- A range of chocolates (and some added artisanal chocolates from Northern Ireland for VIP ticket holders)

- Boxty - and you'll just have to discover what that's about at the event!

- A whole bunch of goodies/tastings from a monthly subscription service of Irish artisanal products

- Custom food tours around Ireland offers

PLUS of course tastings of whiskey, cheese, butter, artisanal bread, honey, relish, cream liqueur, oats.

PLUS at 6:15PM Imen McDonnell will give a talk on Irish farm life, cooking and highlights from her new cookbook.

The cookbook will be on sale at the event - and with a 26% off retail price especially for you!

Look forward to seeing you there for a celebration of all things Irish!

UPDATE as of Feb 12

Tickets now on sale via:

http://www.fareplate.com

Choose from general admission and VIP ticket. Please note the VIP experience offers the option of two set seating times. See link for more details on the two ticket types.

Sponsors and supporters to the event (providing tastings / info) include: Teeling Whiskey, Kerrygold USA (butter and cheeses), Kerrygold Irish Cream Liqueur, Healy's Honey, Irish Beef, OhArtagain (artisanal bread), Ballymaloe Relish, Coole Swan Irish Cream Liqueur (with Belgian chocolate), Butlers Chocolate, Irish Taste Club (monthly subscription service of array of small Irish artisan producers) plus Hanlons Smokehouse and Crafted Ireland, a custom food tour operator. Additional producers to be added shortly.

FAB NEWS! As one of the new features to FarePlate, the new Irish cookbook by Imen McDonnell will be showcased at the event.  Known as @ModernFarmette on Twitter and with her own blog <a>www.farmette.ie,</a>  she has extensive experience in food photography, styling and blogging, having worked for key media groups in the US before she moved to Ireland.  Based in Limerick this cookbook will launch in March.  She will be on-site at the event providing a brief talk, will have several of the recipes featured throughout the afternoon - and on hand to autograph the cookbook.

results.description:
One of the projects currently supported by AID NYC, Kadam Education Initiative (KEI) will be visiting New York City in March. Young women from the Kadam Education Initiative have been invited by LitWorld (a US NGO that supports Kadam Education Initiative) to participate in a series of events for girls organized in connection with the UN Women - CSW Summits in NYC in March 2016. As a welcome to, and in support of KEI, AID NYC will host the group of organizers and young female students ranging between 14 and 21 years old. The event is a roundtable discussion bringing together KEI, AID NYC and New York based organizations who are working to drive successful change within the field of education. The purpose of this event is to provide a unique opportunity for an in-depth exchange between similarly dedicated peoples while KEI is visiting the U.S. This gathering emphasizes networking through discussion; a moderator will facilitate participating speakers as they sit around a dynamic table layout, as well as using this intimate setting to involve any audience. -----------

Association for India's Development (AID) is a volunteer based 501(c)(3) non-profit organization committed to promoting sustainable, equitable and just development. In solidarity with non-violent people's struggles, AID supports grassroots organizations in India and initiates efforts in various interconnected spheres such as agriculture, education, livelihoods, natural resources, health, women's empowerment and social justice.
results.name: Success Stories in Education Reform: Voices from the Grassroots

Choose from general admission and VIP ticket. Please note the VIP experience offers the option of two set seating times. See link for more details on the two ticket types.

Plans for St Patrick's Day? You may wish to add Sat. Mar. 12 to your list! From 4PM - 8PM and enjoy tastings, talks and demos from Irish food and drink producers. results.description:
Drench your self in vibrational healing deeply relaxing healing and rejuvinating with Katie Down

Mindful Music Psychotherapy


contact to schedule

</a>Katie Down, MMT, MT-BC, LCAT, is a board-certified, licensed psychotherapist in the state of New York. She received her master’s degree in music psychotherapy at New York University and additional trauma training at the Institute for Contemporary Psychotherapy and with Laurel Parnell in EMDR and is a member of EMDRIA, the national organization for EMDR practitioners. Katie’s mission for Mindful Music Psychotherapy, is to create an environment of healing, compassion, presence, and joy. Through mindfulness meditation techniques, talk therapy, music and sound, Katie helps people facing issues of grief, depression, anxiety, loss, trauma, and neurological challenges such as stroke and traumatic brain injury. Working on a holistic level with the idea that everyone is entitled to wellness, we look into the root causes of symptoms and chronic issues, through a compassionate, non-judgmental approach giving everyone the encouragement to develop personal strengths and full potential while gaining tools for understanding, accepting, and letting go of emotional, behavioral, psychological blockages.
Benefits from music psychotherapy come through deep listening, creating new neural pathways for optimal health. More info at <a href="http://www.mindfulmusicpsychotherapy.com/">www.mindfulmusicpsychotherapy.com/
C

results.description:
Please join us for this week's sit at 4pm this afternoon at B'nai Keshet (99 South Fullerton Avenue, Montclair), where a small but dedicated group is practicing mindfulness meditation in a Jewish context every Shabbat. There is a beauty and peacefulness when we sit together as a group and support each other's ability to practice.  


This week, we will begin doing a series of mindful movement exercises and segue into silent mindfulness meditation, and may engage in walking meditation if time permits.


We frequently begin with a chant, followed by two separate sits with kavvanot (intentions) inspired by the calendar, the weekly Torah portion or our daily lives. All are welcome and there is no cost to attend. We look forward to seeing you. more information at: http://www.jmcmontclair.com
results.name: Shabbat Meditation

results.description:
Looking to transition soon from meetuo so follow and join our facebook page for updates on the group, art relating to the theme, and more at https://www.facebook.com/groups/ImaginativeIllustratorsNYC/


Today we will be focused and immersive in a specific theme we will work on together as a group.

In today's challenge we will be drawing demons. Demons take various forms from typical winged, hoof, and horned monster, devious humanoid or shadowy figures, to flat out horrific abhorrent abominations from the fiery world below. Today we will create our own Demons and bring hell to earth! Or at least our sketchpads...  

The meetup will be split into three parts: First a half hour of warm-up drawings followed by a break of conceptual discussion, then after an hour and a half drawing your chosen idea and design, lastly we'll discuss each others fully developed drawings and ideas as a group.

So don't forget to bring your supplies and sketchbook as this meetup is going to be drawing focused! Also feel free to bring any reference material that will help out with the theme in addition to what will be provided.

You can find me at the tables on the second floor of the Cranberry Cafe.

I hope to see you there and having fun participating in this new style of meetup and exercising, challenging, or developing your drawing and conceptual skills with other imaginative artists throughout NYC. Any skill level and any style is welcomed!
results.name: Lets Draw Together! Theme: Demons

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour that includes an ice breaker and prizes, light appetizers, and is topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates."

SEE THE VENUE:

http://www.boccaeast.com

HOW IT WILL WORK:

5-5:45pm - Happy Hour complete with light appetizers (flat bread, meat & cheeses - $7 select red & white wine and prosecco) , a fun ice breaker, and  prizes awarded to the two people who get the most matches.

5:45pm - You'll be seated for your first speeddating round.

5:45-6:45 - You'll have approximately* 7-10  three to four minute "mini-dates"

6:45 - Turn in your dating cards to the host and mingle. Matches will be emailed to you within 48 hours.

On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

Get the full details below.

* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$32  - PAY IN ADVANCE ONLY - WE DO NOT ACCEPT PAYMENT AT DOOR

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: https://2016atwysnycspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's  more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. 

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
results.name: Ice Breaker Speeddating- Ages 32-45

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's  more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. 

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour that includes an ice breaker and prizes, light appetizers, and is topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates."

SEE THE VENUE:

http://www.boccaeast.com

HOW IT WILL WORK:

5-5:45pm - Happy Hour complete with light appetizers (meat & cheeses - $8 select red & white wine) , a fun ice breaker, and  prizes awarded to the two people who get the most matches.

5:45pm - You'll be seated for your first speeddating round.

5:45-6:45 - You'll have approximately* 7-10  three to four minute "mini-dates"

6:45 - Turn in your dating cards to the host and mingle. Matches will be emailed to you within 48 hours.

On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

Get the full details below.

* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$32  - PAY IN ADVANCE ONLY - WE DO NOT ACCEPT PAYMENT AT DOOR

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: https://2016atwysnycspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds.


*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

results.description:
Welcome!

If you love to play basketball, but height is not your advantage, come out and play with people who aren't excessively tall! In the tradition of Spud Webb, anyone under 5'8", male or female, is welcome to join us on the court. We'll get some teams together and play some competitive, but relaxed bball-- and without any giant hands in our faces! :-p

We rent out the gym from 5:00-8:00pm. Please arrive at least 5-10 minutes early as the sooner everyone arrives, the sooner we can begin playing. Note that all games stop at 7:45pm as we must be out of the gym no later than 8:00pm. (If you get there late, please only ring the bell once. It is very loud! And it takes us a few minutes to get downstairs.) The gym is on the 10th fl. & has adjoining bathrooms, lockers, and water fountains.

Don't forget:


* You must be no more than 5'8" to play!

* You must RSVP on the site in order to attend!

* To be eligible to play we ask that you sign an annual waiver, which can be found here.


* If you have any problems with the prepay, just shoot one of the organizers a message. 

The Rules:

1. Play by ones and twos to 11 - win by one point.

2. Make it - take it.

3. Backcourt if the ball hits the rim or backboard. Air balls are fair game to put right back up.

4. Jump balls/disputed calls will be determined by a three pointer since the laws of basketball physics are very clear that "the ball never lies."

5. Walls, half-court line, and ceiling are out of bounds. 

6. Usually each team has 1-2 subs. Subs should enter mid-game (one of the teams reaches 6 points) and should start the following game. Teams can regulate themselves but let's just make sure everyone plays!

See you on the court! B-)

***SPECIAL NOTES***

Please do not show up unannounced (without RSVP):

This gym is small and 22 is the maximum number of players we can realistically allow. There is a waiting list if all spots have been taken. If you do show up unannounced we will have to ask you to leave. 

Refund Policy:

A refund/credit is available if you change your RSVP at least 24 hours in advance OR, if you change your RSVP within 24 hours, as long as you post a comment on the event page and someone picks up your spot (BOTH are required).

Lastly...

Feel free to bring your own basketball for shoot-around. And don't forget to clip your fingernails prior to game day. We tried playing with Edward Scissorhands once - it didn't turn out so well.

The Afterparty: 

We'll hit up McSwiggans (393 2nd Avenue @ 23rd St) later!

results.description:
A Conversation About Happiness

Alternating Hosts: George & Michael Y

</a> CitiCorp Atrium Lower Level
153 E 53rd street (Between Lexington and 3rd ave)

3/12: 5:15-7:45pm. Look for our red Meetup Sign.

Note: this is not a support group for those sad or depressed as there are other domains set up for that purpose. Please do not attend if you feel or rationalize that others somehow have the responsibility of cheering you up.

The theory behind these events comes from a classic psychology study showing that by simply talking regularly about happiness we can become much happier.

While we'll depart from them however much we may wish, like by talking about gratitude, acts of kindness, meditation and other happiness techniques, the following list of 14 topics will serve as a backdrop for our discussions.

1. Keep busy and be more active
2. Spend more time socializing
3. Be productive at meaningful work
4. Get better organized and plan things out
5. Stop worrying
6. Lower your expectations and aspirations
7. Develop positive, optimistic thinking
8. Become present oriented
9. Develop an outgoing, social personality
10. Work on a healthy personality
11. Be yourself
12. Eliminate negative feelings and problems
13. Close relationships are the number one source of happiness
14. Put happiness as your most important priority.

Here's some background on the research our group is based on.

In 1980 three New Zealand researchers found that after eight 2-hour conversation sessions about happiness over four weeks, their subjects reported a 22 percent increase in their happiness. Continuing their twice-weekly sessions, by the sixteenth week they reported being 42 percent happier.

Our list of topics comes from Fort Myers, Florida psychologist Michael Fordyce's "14 Fundamentals of Happiness." In 1977, Fordyce pioneered the science of happiness-increase with the world's first experiment designed to boost individual happiness.

That's the group. It's important that our events be fun! So with that in mind, let's get serious about ramping up our enjoyment of life!

At the NE corner of 53rd and Lex., walk down wide steps (see photo) leading to lower outdoor patio. Pass entrance to the subway station on the right, and walk through the revolving door. Walk straight about 30 yards, down a few steps; the Atrium is on the left.

Resources:

For those interested in learning about the major findings from social science research about happiness, and becoming happier, here are links to several excellent peer-reviewed articles that can be downloaded as pdf files for free. (Note: Although these classic articles are somewhat dated, decades of research on happiness reveal that findings on happiness tend to be extremely stable over time.)

Pursuing Happiness: The Architecture of Sustainable Change
By S Lyubomirsky, KM Sheldon and D Schkade, 2005.  21 pages

<a href="http://internal.psychology.illinois.edu/%7Eediener/Documents/Kesebir-Diener_2008.pdf">In Pursuit of Happiness: Empirical Answers to Philosophical Questions
By P Kesebir and E Diener, 2008. 9 pages.

Subjective Well-Being: Three Decades of Progress
By E Diener, EM Suh, RE Lucas and HL Smith, 1999. 27 pages

results.description:
It's St. Patrick's Day season so let's celebrate with Mass at Old St. Patrick's Cathedral followed by a social at Onieals Grand Street afterwards.

Old St. Patrick's, completed in 1815, was the original See of the Archdiocese of New York. It was the second Catholic cathedral in the US and the second Catholic church in New York after St. Peter's, site of our first meetup. In fact Old St. Patrick's was built on land that St. Peter's had purchased for a cemetery. This was also the first Catholic church in the US dedicated to St. Patrick.

In its early days, the Church was a bulwark against anti-Catholic sentiment in New York. It was built behind high walls , its stained-glass windows designed to be outside the reach of rock-throwing from the sidewalk. The Ancient Order of Hibernians squared off against the Know Nothings to protect the Church many times in its early years. And they succeeded, though the original building was damaged by fire in 1866, only to be restored in 1868.

The parish was largely financed by and originally catered to working-class Irish immigrants, despite its proximity to what we now know as Little Italy. Italian immigrants arrived in the 1880s, followed by Chinese and Hispanic immigrants. Young professionals have found a home here in more recent years.

St. John Neumann, the first male American saint, and second American saint after St. Elizabeth Seton (baptized at Old St. Peter's), was ordained here in 1836. The first American Cardinal, John McCloskey, was elevated here in 1875.

Old St. Patrick's has recently been restored once again and remains as a testament to the Catholic faith in New York. As far as pop culture goes, scenes from The Godfather movies were filmed here, John F. Kennedy Jr.'s funeral Mass was held here in 1999.

Mass is at 5:30, social to follow around the corner at Onieals. Old St. Patrick's is one of the sites for the Jubilee Year of Mercy. Just looking at the parish's website, it seems that we should then visit the Church of the Most Precious Blood, 109 Mulberry St., to view the Nativity of Mercy and obtain a plenary indulgence. It's only 5 blocks away, so let's plan on doing that, then we'll hit Onieals, which is on the way. Click HERE for more information about how that works 

See you there!
results.name: St. Patrick's celebration at Old St. Patrick's Cathedral & Onieals Grand Street

group.name: New York Church and a Pub

results.description:
During weekly meetings on Saturday evenings in the East Village of New York City, Atmanivedana das (Atma) and Subhangada devi dasi (Subhie) teach how to hear and chant sanskrit names for God in kirtan and teach a systematic study the Bhagavad-gita As It Is.  Kirtan meditation consists of hearing and chanting sanksrit names for God to the accompaniment of melodious and rhythmic music in order to invoke God's divine mercy and presence.  Bhagavad-gita As It Is is studied according to the ancient, yet unbroken, chain of teachers, as taught originally by Krishna and eventually Sri Caitanya Mahaprabhu, Rupa Goswami, and more recently A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada, the Founder-Acarya of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness.   

Our focus is a systematic and thematic, but not difficult to understand, study of the Bhagavad-gita As It Is.  Everyone will read verses together from the Bhagavad-gita, copies of which will be provided for attendees to reference during the meetup.  Atma and Subhie will together explain the Bhagavad-gita verses according to the ancient tradition that they have studied and lived by for over fifty years, combined.  We will learn about various fascinating topics, such as karma, reincarnation, the soul, the material energy, the Supreme Soul, time, and the relationship between the soul, the material energy, and the Supreme Soul.

Hard cover copies of the beautiful Bhagavad-gita As It Is with the original 700 sanskrit verses, translations, and elaborate purports by A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada, will be available for any member who might choose to take one home for a suggested donation of $10.

This meetup is intended for everyone who is interested without discrimination and regardless of one's familiarity with the subject matter.  Please come and relish this most wonderful discussion and kirtan, celebrating the glories of bhakti yoga, i.e., devotional service to God, who is known according to the Bhagavad-gita by the name Krishna.

Here is the general schedule of our meetups: we begin the evening with a kirtan that lasts about half an hour -- until about 6:00 p.m.  Then, we have a class on Bhagavad-gita As It Is, which lasts for about an hour and a half.  In the class, we will go through verses of the Gita in order, continuing from where the last class left off, with questions pertaining to those verses being encouraged throughout the class.  By about 7:30, the last kirtan begins; it lasts for about 30 minutes.  A sumptuous and nutritious vegetarian dinner is served after that.

Admission to each meetup is free.  Donations for the meetup's expenses are welcome, but not at all required!

Atma is an initiated priest who since 1990 has been studying, teaching, and living according to the teachings of the Bhagavad-gita as taught and followed by A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada. After living in a monastic setting for eight years, Atma resumed his undergraduate education at Brown University, where he hosted weekly programs that focused on kirtan and Bhagavad-gita.  He then enrolled at the University of Chicago Law School from which he graduated in 2004 and from which he received a merit scholarship.  Atma practices law in courts around the country, with his office in Long Island, and his concentration in securities and derivative litigation.  His primary goal is to imbibe in his own life the devotional teachings of the Bhagavad-gita and to share the same with others as a humble offering to God.

Subhie has been living her life according to the teachings of the Bhagavad-gita since 1991 and is also an initiated priest.  Subhie lived in a monastic setting until 2005.   From 1991 to 2005, Subhie taught Bhagavad-gita in Croatia, Serbia, Greece, Germany, and United Kingdom.  Subhie spent several years studying Vedic knowledge in India, primarily in the holy town, Vrindavana.  After 2005, Subhie resumed her undergraduate education in religion at the University of London -- and then locally at Queens College, after she moved to New York and married Atma.  Subhie completed her Master's degree in teaching at Queens College and is a school teacher.

results.description:
The bailouts are widely misunderstood by most of the public.  I would estimate that 80% of Americans believe that under TARP, the government just gave (not loaned, just gave) hundreds of billions of dollars to the big banks, who just kept the money and used it to pay themselves big bonuses, which is not true.

The most outrageous slander against the financial establishment has been piling up, with virtually no one in the media standing up to these wanton distortions.  In this context, we have politicians like Bernie Sanders, who wants to radically reform the system with no background of financial expertise, gaining popularity.

At this event, we will go over what actually happened, as opposed to the hyperbole bandied about by politicians and the sensationalistic media.

Summer 2006: Real estate prices nationwide hit their peak and start declining.  This is problematic because 90% of the country (not just Wall Street, but also the home buyers, politicians, regulators, and bond rating agencies) had believed that real estate prices were guaranteed to go up indefinitely.  If real estate prices were to decline significantly, it could undermine the whole banking system.

Summer 2007: The decline of real estate values nationwide gathers momentum.  It becomes evident that in an environment of declining real estate values, the assumptions behind the AAA ratings of many mortgage bonds will be violated and the bonds will have to be re-rated, often to junk.  The rating agencies scramble to re-rate all the impacted bonds, but it's a mammoth undertaking and it will take years for them to catch up.

August 2007: Countrywide Financial, one of the least responsible lenders in the country, runs into financial trouble and is rescued by being acquired by Bank of America, which was completed in January 2008. This move was very unfortunate for Bank of America.

November 2007: Charles Prince, CEO of Citigroup, resigns in disgrace after very poor performance of Citi due to excessive exposure to poorly performing subprime loans. He is replaced by Vikram Pandit.

March 2008: Bear Stearns fails due to excessive exposure to defaulting subprime loans and is rescued by JP Morgan Chase with help from the government.

Sept 14, 2008: Merrill Lynch, an investment bank failing due to excessive exposure to subprime loans, agrees to be acquired by Bank of America, a transaction which was completed in January 2009.

Note that the financial crisis would have been worse had Glass-Steagall not been repealed, because it would have prevented the rescues of Bear Stearns and Merrill Lynch.

Sept 2008: Lehman Brothers is on the verge of bankruptcy. Over the preceding months, several other banks had considered rescuing / acquiring it, but all backed after a closer look at the assets, seeing just how bad they were. The Fed and Treasury try desperately to save it, but they don’t have the legal authority to outright bail it out, and on Sept 15, 2008, Lehman declares bankruptcy.

Late September 2008: After the failure of Lehman, financial panic freezes credit markets. Hank Paulson (Secretary of the Treasury) and Ben Bernanke (Fed Chairman) approach congress asking for permission to use $[masked] billion to bail out the banks. The first question they were asked is “Can’t this wait until after the election?” (the election was scheduled for the beginning of November). Bernanke stresses that credit markets are frozen, banks aren’t lending to each other, let alone anybody else, and normal companies cannot get the routine loans they need to stay in business.

September[masked]: The House of Representatives rejects the bailout; stock markets crash.

Oct 1, 2008: The Senate passes an amended bailout proposal and the House passes it on October 3. President Bush immediately signs it into law.

An important feature of the bailouts is that all banks have to be bailed out, whether they need it or not, and whether their management wants it or not. Otherwise those banks that get bailed out could be stigmatized and experience runs. Banks that refuse to take the money are threatened by the government with dire regulatory harassment unless they relent, so that all the banks eventually agree to take the money.

The banks are prohibited from paying back the bailout money until the government gives them permission, and they are prohibited from issuing their employees large bonuses until they pay back the bailout money. Somehow AIG (not a bank) finds a loophole in this and issues large bonuses in spite of still owing a very large amount of TARP money.

The government takes over Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the biggest two bailouts of all.  The government really had no choice but to bail them out, as those two entities were created by the government, and their whole purpose for existence revolves around an implicit government guarantee that, if push comes to shove, they will be bailed out by the Federal government.

In the spring of 2009, the government conducts accounting “stress tests” to see if the banks can weather another storm. Those who pass the stress tests are to be permitted to pay back the bailout money, which most of the big banks do immediately, in early June 2009. Citigroup is still in bad shape, and Bank of America also is not fit to repay, mostly due to its unfortunate acquisition of other, far less healthy, banks. Many small banks are struggling and will remain unable to repay the bailout money for years, even until 2016.

The repayment of the TARP money by most of the big banks in June of 2009 gets almost no media attention, being probably the most under covered event of the 21st century.

Later in 2009, the banks that had repaid their TARP money issue bonuses to their employees. It should be noted that under normal conditions, a banker’s bonus is a large part of their routine pay, so not issuing bonuses would be effectively a large pay cut. The public, believing that the TARP money has not been repaid and not understanding the normal nature of bankers’ pay, is enraged.

In September of 2009, “Capitalism: A Love Story”, a Michael Moore movie about the financial crisis, hits the theaters. In it, Michael Moore makes a big act of driving an armored truck around Manhattan to all the big banks demanding that they repay the TARP money. Bankers, knowing that anything intelligent that they say to him will wind up on the cutting room floor, refuse to interview him, and he never gets past the security guards. Whether we should believe that nobody ever told Moore that those banks had already repaid the money is left as an exercise for the reader.

2011: Ron Paul and Bernie Sanders (a strange pair of bedfellows if ever I saw one) get legislation through congress dictating that the Fed is to be audited. The audit reveals that many short-term secret loans were made by the Fed during the crisis. In early 2009, these loans totalled $1.2 trillion, which was the peak outstanding. This was almost entirely paid back by January of 2010.

Bernie Sanders,

on his website, to this date

, claims that his Fed audit revealed that $16 trillion in secret loans had happened and makes it sound like none of it has been paid back. To turn $1.2 trillion into $16 trillion, some accounting tricks are done. If I borrow $100 from you Thursday to be paid back in a week, and the next Thursday take out another $100, one-week loan to finance paying the first back, and then repeat the process every week for a year at which point I pay it off, Bernie Sanders’ accounting would call that 52 x $100 == $5200 in loans. But it’s paid back at the end of the year, and it was never more than $100. It was effectively a $100 loan for one year.

Above: the total outstanding debt of the allegedly $16 trillion (actual peak of $1.2 trillion) in loans exposed by the Fed audit.

Most news sources, like Sanders, report the loans as $16 trillion, and insinuate that none of it has been repaid.

2016: All the big banks and AIG have repaid their TARP money long ago.  Fannie and Freddie have paid back.  Some small banks still have yet to pay back.  GM and Chrysler still owe bailout money.

results.name: 2008 Financial Crisis and Bailouts: A Timeline

results.description:
*Shooting animals to death when the intense, unnatural confinement causes them to engage in aggressive or self destructive, stereotypical behaviors

*Continuously/routinely inflicting painful punishments on animals who do not perform under a diabolical mixture of stress, fear and deprivation of all that is natural, as "necessary" to keep the animals obedient, the crowds entertained and the million$$$ rolling in.

*Cynically scoffing in the face of USDA *minimal* requirements of animal welfare, including adequate veterinary care, reasonable opportunities to engage in natural behaviors, sufficient space, exercise and drinking water.

The atrocities go on and on and on:

http://circusprotest.com/


http://www.mediapeta.com/peta/PDF/RinglingFactsheet.pdf

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mRZt6SdNs7g

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Y6WKI8eKI4

http://www.peta.org/issues/animals-in-entertainment/circuses.aspx

Here are the details of the anti-Ringling demonstration:

WHERE: Ringling's 3 Ring Circus of Horror and Atrocity

The Prudential Center, 165 Mulberry Street, Newark, NJ, 07102 

WHEN: Saturday March 12, 2016

TIME: 6:00 - 8:00 pm

ASSEMBLY POINT: The corner of Edison & Mulberry Streets in the Ironbound Section of Newark, right outside the Prudential Center (see below map:)
MAP: http://www.mapquest.com/?version=1.0&hk=8-88kqUwFN

PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION: from NYC -Penn Station in NYC, one train stop to Newark Penn Station. Go outside and you will see the large Prudential Center sign on top of the building approx 1 block away.

DETAILS ON PARKING: There is parking on sidestreets everywhere in the vicinity of Mulberry & Lafayette Streets, and a number of municipal lots in the local area as well. Please think ahead and bring some quarters for metered parking, if you aren't lucky enough to find free parking (which is ample!)

There will also be protests at Ringling's following performances:

Sunday March 13, 2-4 pm, 6-8 pm


Please help FAUN and our friends/allies stand up for animals enslaved by the heartless, horrific enterprise known as Ringling Bros Circus. Animals are enslaved, abused and forced to spend their dismal, horrendous lives engaging in behaviors wholly unnatural to them, performing under constant threat of pain and punishment by this ravenous cash machine of a "circus". and get treated like garbage even as those who survive all the horror, a joyless life of mechanistic use and abuse, approach convalescence.

Again, we will have signs, leaflets and relevant props. If you have something you want to bring, that's fine, but all you NEED to bring is YOURSELF, a heart full of empathy/compassion and a voice to demonstrate your love for pachyderms, primates, bears, big cats, all creatures great and small.

Blessed be ALL animals, FIGHT for their rights!!!
results.name: **"FAUN vs. Ringling: Animal Circus, Begone!" demo @ Prudential in Newark, NJ!**

results.description:
The Metropolitan Museum of Art, otherwise affectionately known as the Met, is without a doubt New York's favorite museum- and for good reason. This vast museum holds art for everyone's eye. Into Bernini? Gotcha covered. Do they have Rembrandt's paintings? You betcha. Is it possible you won't find something to enjoy in here? A snow ball has a better chance in... well, you know. So, whatever type of art you enjoy, or even if you're not sure what type of art you like- come out and enjoy the museum with us.

A few of the current exhibits, click on each to find out a little about them:

Vigée Le Brun: Woman Artist in Revolutionary France

Design for Eternity: Architectural Models From the Ancient Americas

Korea: 100 Years of Collecting at the Met

 and many, many more...

And I should take the opportunity to say it's "Pay as you wish," meaning you can literally pay as little money as you wish. The recommended donation is $20, but if you want to give a dollar, that's perfectly fine. It's not just a great museum, but one you can visit on a budget, as well.

So look forward to good art, good company, and possibly a decent meal after if enough people are interested. See you then!
results.name: Let's Go to the Met

blessed be ALL animals, FIGHT for their rights!!!

results.description:
Profile 
“Ashin Kusaladhamma”

Born at the end of 1966 in Temanggung, Indonesia. He obtained a Bachelor’s Degree major in Management from the Faculty of Economics, the Parahyangan Catholic University, Bandung and completed his Master’s Degree major in Financial Management from the Prasetiya Mulya Institute of Management in Jakarta.

After working for a few years, he decided to renounce his lay life and lead a monastic life. He obtained his lower ordination as a Buddhist novice in 1998 and got his higher ordination in Myanmar under Chanmyay Sayādaw Ashin Janakābhivaṁsa in 2001.

During his years of staying in Myanmar, he continued his study and obtained his Bachelor’s Degree in the Buddha Dhamma from the International Theravāda Buddhist Missionary University, Yangon; and also got private guidance to study Buddhism from some learned Myanmar monks.

He practiced insight meditation (vipassanā bhāvanā) intensively for a few years in some meditation centers in Myanmar, such as Chanmyay Yeiktha Forest Meditation Center – Hmawbi, Paṇḍitārāma Shwe Taung Gon Meditation Center – Yangon, Paṇḍitārāma Hse Main Gon Forest Meditation Center – Bago. He also practiced tranquillity meditation (samatha bhāvanā) at Pa Auk Tawya Forest Meditation Center – Mawlamyine.

He is the author of “Ilustrated Chronicle of the Buddha” which narrates the life of the Buddha chronologically. It was translated into Indonesian and Burmese and was published in 2006.

Since he has come back to Indonesia, he delivers Dhamma talks, teaches Buddhism to children and adult, and gives insight meditation instructions to local and foreign yogis at Indonesia Satipaṭṭhāna Meditation Center (ISMC) either in its city center in Jakarta or its forest center in Bacom - Puncak, and also in some other cities in Indonesia.

Meditation session: 6-7 PM

Q & A session: 7-8 PM

Wear comfortable loose clothes. No tank tops, shorts or short skirts please.

For more information, please feel free to leave a comment or email me at [masked].

** Free of charge **

** Donations welcome **

results.description:
We don’t like to think about it, or perhaps we do, but death is an integral part of life and should be honored through storytelling.


Did you preserve the frog you dissected in high school in a jar, much to your mother’s dismay? Or did you save your only child’s very first baby tooth? Or after your father died, did you find your grandmother’s art deco jewelry box in the back of a closet with a lock of his hair from his first baby hair cut? Or maybe you have a child’s urn--with the remains of your first dog--who your parents insisted on cremating rather than burying in the back yard?


So bring your bones, feathers, teeth, ashes, locks of hair, hair art, body parts preserved in a jar, death-related art, cremation jewelry or urns and share their story. . .Every Thing (death and life-related) has a story.

Show & Tale is like Antiques Roadshow meets The Moth, or your favorite Pinterest board come to life!

Everyone is welcome to share with a 3 minute time limit. No judges, no prizes, no competition. And no need to practice! Just Show your object and share its Tale.


Remember you don’t have to show and tell. . .you can just look and listen; observers are always welcome!
results.name: Show & Tale: Morbid Anatomy

results.description:
ShapeShifter Lab and the Brooklyn Digital Conservatory Present: Digital + Acoustic Sessions Part II 

Live Vocals and Ableton Live + Intro to Basic Video Integration With Ableton Live 

Curated By Dan FreeMan (CØm1x) 

Hosted By Matthew Garrison and ShapeShifter Lab 

Free Workshop: 6:30 - 8:00 PM 

Live Performances: 8:30 - 11:00 

We continue the Digital + Acoustic Sessions tackling techniques in which Ableton Live can be integrated with vocals in live performance. From simply adding effects to vocals to doing live looping and sampling with vocals to create and improvise on the fly with Ableton Live and Push. The free workshop will be led by Ableton Certified Trainer Dan Freeman (CØm1x) and will feature Brazilian vocalist Candida Borges. 

The workshop will also touch on some basic ways of integrating video into live sets using Max for Live patches. 


Following the workshop, there will be live performances by musical and digital visual artists integrating live and digital performance.
results.name: Digital + Acoustic Sessions Part 2

The March 12th Mixed Doubles Tennis Wine and Beer Social!

When: Saturday March 12th, 6:30 pm - 11:00 pm

Where:

TCR: The Club of Riverdale, 2600 Netherland Ave, Bronx, NY 10463

What:

Join us for a FUN night of Mixed Doubles competition! Format will be timed rotations on 6 gorgeous indoor tennis courts in a 120,000 sq ft facility. Check-In at 6:30 pm and play time on the courts will consist of up to 3 hours from 7:00 pm - 10:00 pm.

From 10:00 pm - 11:00 pm, finish off the event with your new tennis friends and some final laughs over food, wine and beer (This has been a great highlight of the Tennis Social Event, not to be missed)

Dress:


Tennis Attire and Non-Marking Tennis Sneakers (Only)

Level of Play:

All levels of play are welcome

Beginners and Advanced Beginners will play with each other Advanced and Intermediate Players will play with each

Tennis Pros will participate with all players on the courts

Cost:

$90 Non-TCR Members: If you enroll on a Friday or Saturday before the event

$75 Non-TCR Members: If you enroll on a Thursday or prior for the event (Best Offer If Not A TCR Member)

$50 Non-TCR Member Guests: Guests can enjoy the Social and TCR facility (i.e pool, sauna, steam room, etc), but not play tennis

$50 TCR Members: Can participate in all aspects of the event

Structure:

Competition is limited to 36 Players Only

Men & Women

Singles & Couples

It will be fun, social environment that will have plenty of hitting and friendly mixed doubles competition

Itinerary of Event:

Check-In: 6:30 pm

Tennis Play: 7:00 pm - 10:00 pm

Wine & Beer: 10:00 pm - 11:00 pm

RSVP: Call[masked] or email [masked] The only way to confirm your reservation and to participate as one of the 36 players is to provide payment before the event. This event will sell out quickly, so don't delay.

The following information is needed to secure your reservation:

Name(s) of attendees:

TCR Member or Guest: Yes: $50 / No: $75 (Paying Thurs or Prior) / No: $90 (Paying Friday or Saturday) /

Credit Card Number:

CVV:Expiration:

Name as it Appears on Card:

Cardholder Address:

How to Arrive:


You may be able to get a FREE ride by sharing with another participant of the event or carpooling with others via UBER as another alternative. If so, please email, [masked] to see if there is any availability, otherwise these are the other options:

FREE Pick Up Via Car

If space is available you can meet on the North West corner (by the T-Mobile Store) at 96 Street and Broadway at 6:00 pm. Coordinate with Robert at[masked] if you would like this.

By Car on Your Own

Henry Hudson Southbound: Take Kappock Street exit 18 off Henry Hudson Pkwy, turn left 180° at stop sign onto Kappock St. At second light turn left onto Netherland Ave. TCR club is located in the Century building.

Henry Hudson Northbound: Take Kappock Street exit 18 of Henry Hudson Pkwy, continue off the exit onto Kappock St., then turn left onto Netherland Ave. TCR club is located in the Century building.

Manhattan East Side: Take Deegan 87 to 230th St Exit 10, left at light. Left onto Broadway under the elevated train. Make first right onto 230th st and at road end turn left onto Irwin Ave. Follow up hill and turn right onto Kappock St, first light make a right onto Netherland Ave.

By Bus from Manhattan

BxM1: Bus runs from East Midtown, Manhattan directly to the club. Manhattan pick ups start at 3 Ave/33rd St. and goes up 3rd Ave till 97s street before it goes off 3rd Avenue. Bus is scheduled to pickup every 12 to 30 minutes depending on time of day. Stops right next to club at Kappock St. and Knolls Crescent. Here goes the full bus schedule stops: http://bustime.mta.info/m/?q=BxM1

#1 Train:

Take the 1 train to 207th St. and take the 20 bus to Kappock and Knolls Crescent.

OR

Take the 1 train to 231st St. and take the 10 bus to Kappock and Knolls Crescent.

By Metro North Train

Metro-north stop at Spuytin Duyvul station, 5 minute walk to TCR.

Parking:
There is paid parking available in the Century building's garage, with TCR validation prices range from $8/2hrs, $9/3hrs, $14/over 3 hours. There is also FREE street parking available within 1 or 2 blocks of the club.

How to Enter:

TCR is located in the century building, one flight up from the parking garage. If you enter through the loading dock, it is located one flight down. If you enter through the main lobby of the building, TCR is two flights down.

Just Ring the Doorbell to allow entry.

Questions: Call[masked] and speak with your Host and Elite USPTA Certified Tennis Pro, Robert


SEE YOU ON THE COURTS...

he Women of the World Poetry Slam (WOWps) brings together 72 of the best women slam poets to compete against one another for a chance to be crowned champion. In addition to the competition, each day of the festival features poetry workshops, themed open mics and special events designed to foster community-building among participants.

With New York as the backdrop of the 2016 Women of the World Poetry Slam, the festival promises to be an unforgettable event. Information on festival tickets and passes will be released in the coming months.

results.description:
Unfortunately, I am UNABLE TO ATTEND TONIGHT'S DANCE but I did send an email to all the attendees so Please LOOK FOR IT & READ IT BEFORE YOU GO!  Have fun and try to post some pics if you can.  __________________________________________________

***WANT TO EXERCISE AND HAVE FUN AT THE SAME TIME? ATTEND A CONTRA DANCE!!!


TRY TO GRAB SOMETHING SMALL TO EAT BEFORE THE DANCE.  (Please arrive by 7 pm!)  

ARRIVE AT THE VENUE @ 7 PM.

BEGINNER LESSONS BEGIN @ 7:30 PM.

DANCING FOR ALL BEGIN @ 8:00 PM till 10:45 PM.

This is a Special Annual Event called, 'The Winter Meltdown.'

Mary Wesley is the Caller and the LIVE BAND IS CALLED, "Cardinal Direction!" (SEE BELOW FOR ADDITIONAL INFO.)

Cedar Stanistreet will be playing on Fiddle

Rebecca Bosworth-Clemens on Clarinet and

John Coté on Guitar, Feet, Didgeridoo and Jaw Harp!

______________________________________________________

RULES TO FOLLOW FOR CONTRA DANCING:

NO SCENTED DEODORANT, NO PERFUME, NO COLOGNE,
NO SMOKING, NO ALCOHOL, & NO HIGH HEALS.

Wear clothing that is LIGHT & COMFORTABLE & Easy to Move Around In. SHOES THAT ARE COMFORTABLE AS WELL, THAT WON'T FALL OFF YOUR FEET FROM MOVING AROUND. If you can walk, you can Contra!

Men might want to bring a Change of Shirt. If you have dance shoes, please bring them along. If not, you might be asked to brush off the bottoms of your shoes if you don't have other shoes to change into for the dance, (to protect the floors.)

Men can ask Women to dance and Women can ask Men.
Come alone or with a friend. People generally switch around partners for each dance which might last b/w 8 & 12 minutes long. The steps are repeated throughout the dance. A Lesson will be provided at 7:30 pm, half an hour before the dance will begin. Ask your partner to help you out if you don't know what to do.

There are also lessons on youtube if you are so inclined. You can look under Contra 101 or Beginner Contra Dancing Steps. They will show you the basic steps and the patterns will be repeated for each dance.

If you let them know it's your first time there when you pay, you will get a FREE PASS to return. The NYC Contra Dance website is: <a>www.cdny.org.</a> You will want to bring your own water bottle and a way to recognize it. A microfiber towel might be helpful, too, if it's hot in the dance room which it usually is.

_______________________________________________________

TONIGHT'S BAND is Massachusetts-based and called, 'Cardinal Direction,' (formerly Firefly) who brings beautiful melodies and relentless energy to dance floors and listening audiences across the Northeast.

Their repertoire is drawn from the Irish, New England, and Quebecois traditions, and seamlessly mixes oldies-but-goodies with modern compositions. They take particular pleasure in playing for Contra Dances, where their love of the drive and flow of the dance comes across clearly in their music.

If you have any questions feel free to ask. You may forward a message or call me at[masked]-1386. Pam
results.name: CONTRA DANCE IN NYC *LIVE BAND* *LESSON* *NO EXP NECESSARY* *WINTER MELTDOWN!*

results.description:
Sammy Social is a member of several social groups in the city.  One particular day Sammy attended several events, met with friends and toured some historic sites near Herald Square.  By the end of the night Sammy met a horrible fate and the police need your help to solve this case!   Join us for this fun night where you will join with other members of our group to set out on a mission to find clues to solve Sammy's case.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

$10 in advance only - prepay here:

http://nysnmurdermyst.eventbrite.com

All ATWYS members who pay in advance for this event will receive a promo code for $7 off a speeddating event as well as $5 off our Mix & Mingle Happy Hour. Please be sure to check your eventbrite order confirmation for the promo codes to use to redeem your discount.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

How it works:

-Arrive at The Playwright for socializing, cocktails and registration.

-If you don't have a team we will put you with other fun people in teams of 4-5.

-Once you are on a team you will receive a sheet retracing Sammy's steps that day.  You will go out into the neighborhood to find clues and fact that will help you solve Sammy's Case.  Along the way you will also learn a little NYC history!

-Each group will have 90 minutes to find as many clues and solve the case.  You will return to The Playwright for more socializing, cocktails and food if you wish, while we tally up the scores.

Can I come alone?  Yes, 98% of those attending will likely come on their own.

Dress code?  Be comfortable but keep it neat.

What is included?  $10 includes admission to the hunt and drink specials at the bar.
results.name: The Great Midtown Murder Mystery Scavenger Hunt and Party

results.description:
I'll be camping between Hikes. I plan to get into camp after dark, build a small fire to keep warm for a bit, then head to bed. I'll be packing up early the next morning to head to another event.

The group size limit for camping in the Catskills is 9. I will be making this a waitlist only event.  First dibs will go to those who are already on the confirmed RSVP list for an HVH hike in the Catskills for Saturday and Sunday of this weekend.

What to Bring:

It is winter and it will be cold. You need a good sleeping bag rated to 10 degrees F or lower. In addition to a sleeping bag, you need a very good sleeping pad. It is important to have insulation between you and the ground. The filling in your sleeping bag that is underneath you will be compressed and provide no insulation. I highly recommend a sleeping pad with an R value of at least 5. (Hint: most closed cell foam pads have a 2.5 R value. If you double them up you will have a combined R value of 5.)

You will also need something to keep the snow and wind off of you while you sleep. Since we're below the tree line, any small 3 season tent should do. You want something with good ventilation so that you don't get soaked in condensation over night. Avoid a big "princess" tent; these don't stand up well with a snow load.

I also ask that all participants bring a small bundle of wood.  You can purchase local wood.  There are strict regulations on transporting firewood within the State of New York.  If you plan to carry wood from home, it must be kiln dried.  If you want to see why this is so important, go check out the birch trees in the Adirondacks.
results.how_to_find_us: Jason: Black Subaru Baja. Cell: 201.310.6346
results.name: Winter Camping in the Catskills
